intro: Rosa chavinii var. typica, commonly known as the Chavín rose, is a species native to the highlands of Peru. It is a shrub that typically grows to a height of 1 to 2 meters, featuring thorny stems and dark green, lobed leaves. The plant produces fragrant, semi-double flowers in shades of pink and red, which bloom in the spring. Its botanical characteristics include a woody stem structure and a preference for well-drained, acidic soils. It is often found in rocky or mountainous regions, where it thrives in full sun.
